elements.content: By introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates with two types of structures, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]·2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2·4H2O(Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3), have been prepared and structurally characterized. The interconnection of La(III) ions in 1 by bridging H6L anions resulted in a 3D network with tunnels running along the a-axis, the oxalate anions are located inside the above tunnels, and each forms two five-membered chelating rings with two La(III) ions. All four phosphonate groups of the H6L anion are bidentate and singly protonated; its two amine groups are also protonated. Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural, and their structures feature a pillared layered structure. The layer is formed by Ln(III) ions interconnected by oxalate and −NH(CH2PO3H)2 moieties of H6L anions, and the organic groups of the tetraphosphonate ligand act as the pillars. Alternatively, their structures can be described as the lanthanide tetraphosphonate layers being cross-linked by oxalate anions (pillars). The H6L anions in 2 and 3 are hexadentate, and each bridges with six Ln(III) ions; two phosphonate groups are bidentate, and the other two are unidentate. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 exhibit strong emission bands in the blue, red light, and near-IR region, respectively.
elements.clean_text: By introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates with two types of structures, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]⋅2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2⋅4H2O(Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3), have been prepared and structurally characterized. The interconnection of La(III) ions in 1 by bridging H6L anions resulted in a 3D network with tunnels running along the a-axis, the oxalate anions are located inside the above tunnels, and each forms two five-membered chelating rings with two La(III) ions. All four phosphonate groups of the H6L anion are bidentate and singly protonated; its two amine groups are also protonated. Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural, and their structures feature a pillared layered structure. The layer is formed by Ln(III) ions interconnected by oxalate and -NH(CH2PO3H)2 moieties of H6L anions, and the organic groups of the tetraphosphonate ligand act as the pillars. Alternatively, their structures can be described as the lanthanide tetraphosphonate layers being cross-linked by oxalate anions (pillars). The H6L anions in 2 and 3 are hexadentate, and each bridges with six Ln(III) ions; two phosphonate groups are bidentate, and the other two are unidentate. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 exhibit strong emission bands in the blue, red light, and near-IR region, respectively.

elements.content: By introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates with two types of structures, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]·2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2·4H2O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3), have been prepared and structurally characterized. The structures of 1−3 can be viewed as lanthanide-tetraphosphonate-based open frameworks being decorated by the second ligand. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 exhibit strong emission bands in the blue, red light, and near-IR region, respectively.
elements.clean_text: By introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates with two types of structures, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]⋅2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2⋅4H2O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3), have been prepared and structurally characterized. The structures of 1-3 can be viewed as lanthanide-tetraphosphonate-based open frameworks being decorated by the second ligand. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 exhibit strong emission bands in the blue, red light, and near-IR region, respectively.

elements.content: The search for novel porous inorganic−organic hybrid materials based on metal phosphonates is of great research interest due to their potential applications in electrooptics, ion exchange, catalysis, and sensors. Though a great number of metal phosphonates have been reported, reports on lanthanide phosphonates are still limited, and many of them are based on X-ray powder diffraction. Lanthanide phosphonates normally have low solubility in water and other organic solvents; hence it is rendered difficult to obtain single crystals suitable for X-ray structural analysis. To improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide phosphonates, additional functional groups such as crown ether, carboxylate, hydroxyl, and amine groups have been attached to the phosphonate ligand. The elucidation of the structures of lanthanide phosphonates is very important since these compounds may exhibit useful luminescent properties in the visible and near-IR region. Results from our previous studies indicate that introducing a second ligand such as 5-sulfoisophthalic acid (H3BTS) and oxalate whose lanthanide compounds have good solubility as well as very good crystallinity into the lanthanide−phosphonate system can lead to novel luminescent lanthanide−phosphonate hybrids with better solubility and crystallinity. Results of our studies also indicate that the combination of two types of ligands could enhance the energy transfer efficiency from ligands to lanthanide ions and improve the luminescent properties of the lanthanide compounds due to the so-called “antenna effect”. We are now extending such an approach from lanthanide mono- and diphosphonates to the lanthanide polyphosphonates, whose solubility and crystallinity problems are even worse, except for polyphosphonic acids derived from polyaza-crown ethers. Our research efforts led to three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]·2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2·4H2O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3). Herein we report their syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The search for novel porous inorganic-organic hybrid materials based on metal phosphonates is of great research interest due to their potential applications in electrooptics, ion exchange, catalysis, and sensors. Though a great number of metal phosphonates have been reported, reports on lanthanide phosphonates are still limited, and many of them are based on X-ray powder diffraction. Lanthanide phosphonates normally have low solubility in water and other organic solvents; hence it is rendered difficult to obtain single crystals suitable for X-ray structural analysis. To improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide phosphonates, additional functional groups such as crown ether, carboxylate, hydroxyl, and amine groups have been attached to the phosphonate ligand. The elucidation of the structures of lanthanide phosphonates is very important since these compounds may exhibit useful luminescent properties in the visible and near-IR region. Results from our previous studies indicate that introducing a second ligand such as 5-sulfoisophthalic acid (H3BTS) and oxalate whose lanthanide compounds have good solubility as well as very good crystallinity into the lanthanide-phosphonate system can lead to novel luminescent lanthanide-phosphonate hybrids with better solubility and crystallinity. Results of our studies also indicate that the combination of two types of ligands could enhance the energy transfer efficiency from ligands to lanthanide ions and improve the luminescent properties of the lanthanide compounds due to the so-called "antenna effect". We are now extending such an approach from lanthanide mono- and diphosphonates to the lanthanide polyphosphonates, whose solubility and crystallinity problems are even worse, except for polyphosphonic acids derived from polyaza-crown ethers. Our research efforts led to three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]⋅2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2⋅4H2O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3). Herein we report their syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties.

elements.content: Materials and Instrumentations. N,N,N ‘ ,N ‘-Tetramethylphosphono-1,4-diaminobutane, (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2 (H8L), was prepared by a Mannich-type reaction according to procedures described previously. Its purity was checked by elemental analysis as well as 1H and 31P NMR measurements. All other chemicals were obtained from Shanghai Reagent Factory and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the 4000−400 cm-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns (Cu Kα) were collected in a sealed glass capillary on a XPERT-MPD θ−2θ diffractometer. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer with a resolution of 0.2 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Instrumentations. N,N,N ‘ ,N ‘-Tetramethylphosphono-1,4-diaminobutane, (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2 (H8L), was prepared by a Mannich-type reaction according to procedures described previously. Its purity was checked by elemental analysis as well as 1H and 31P NMR measurements. All other chemicals were obtained from Shanghai Reagent Factory and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns (Cu Kα) were collected in a sealed glass capillary on a XPERT-MPD θ-2θ diffractometer. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer with a resolution of 0.2 nm.

elements.content: Preparation of [La 2 (ox) 2 (H 6 L)] · 2H 2 O (1) and Ln 2 (ox) 2 (H 6 L)(H 2 O) 2 · 4H 2 O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3). The methods used for the syntheses of the three compounds are similar. A mixture of 0.2 mmol Ln2O3 (0.065 g of La2O3, 0.067 g of Nd2O3, or 0.070 g of Eu2O3), 0.2 mmol H8L (0.092 g), and 0.40 mmol H2C2O4 (0.050 g) in 10 mL of distilled water was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (25 mL) and then heated at 180 °C for 5 days. Crystals of 1 (colorless, brick), 2 (purple, plate), and 3 (colorless, needle) were collected in ca. 77%, 78%, and 73% yield, respectively (based on lanthanide). The initial and final pH values of the resultant solution are about 3.5 and 4.5, respectively. Elemental analysis for 1:  C12H26La2N2O22P4 (M r = 952.05). Calcd:  C, 15.13; H, 2.73; N, 2.94%. Found:  C, 15.29; H, 2.66; N, 2.85%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3405(s), 3005(s), 2768(m), 1695(m), 1470(vs), 1312(s), 1175(vs), 1111(s), 1070(s), 988(s), 928(s), 791(s), 725(m), 604(m), 570(s), 467(s). Elemental analysis for 2:  C12H34N2Nd2O26P4 (M r = 1034.77). Calcd:  C, 13.92; H, 3.28; N, 2.70%. Found:  C, 13.78; H, 3.46; N, 2.98%. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  3429(s), 3003(s), 2778(s), 2613, 1660(vs), 1446(s), 1313(s), 1154(s), 992(s), 936(s), 791(m), 718(s), 606(m), 568(m), 530(m). Elemental analysis for 3:  C12H34N2Eu2O26P4 (M r = 1050.21). Calcd:  C, 13.71; H, 3.24; N, 2.67%. Found:  C, 13.29; H, 3.46; N, 2.75%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3427(vs), 2614(m), 1706(s), 1631(vs), 1457(m), 1318(s), 1091(vs), 1017(s), 937(s), 790(s), 717(m), 607(s), 554(s), 532(s), 492(s).

The initial and final pH values of the resultant solution are about 3.5 and 4.5, respectively. Elemental analysis for 1: C12H26La2N2O22P4 (M r = 952.05). Calcd: C, 15.13; H, 2.73; N, 2.94%. elements.content: Single-Crystal Structure Determination. Single crystals of 1 − 3 were mounted on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Intensity data were collected by the narrow frame method at 293 K. The data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for empirical absorption based on multiscan technique. Both structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms except those for water molecules in compounds 2 and 3 were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms for water molecules in compounds 2 and 3 were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1 − 3 are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths for 1 − 3 are listed in Table . More details on the crystallographic studies, as well as atom displacement parameters are given in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: Single-Crystal Structure Determination. Single crystals of 1 - 3 were mounted on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data were collected by the narrow frame method at 293 K. The data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for  empirical absorption based on multiscan technique. Both structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms except those for water molecules in compounds 2 and 3 were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms for water molecules in compounds 2 and 3 were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1 - 3 are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths for 1 - 3 are listed in Table . More details on the crystallographic studies, as well as atom displacement parameters are given in the Supporting Information.

a  Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms. For 1:  (#1) x + 1, y, z; (#2) x + 1, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (#3) x, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (#4) −x + 1, −y, −z + 1; (#5) −x + 2, −y, −z + 1. For 2 and 3:  (#1) −x + 1, −y + 2, −z + 1; (#2) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1; (#3) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 2; (#4) −x + 1, −y + 2, −z + 2; (#5) 1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z; (#6) −x, 2 − y, 1 − z.

Compounds 1−3 are the first members of lanthanide oxalate tetraphosphonates. They form two different types of 3D network structures. Their structures can be viewed as lanthanide phosphonate-based networks being decorated by oxalate anions. Results of this study provide further evidence that we can greatly improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide tetraphosphonates by introducing oxalic acid as the second metal linker. Such a technique has been used successfully in designing luminescent lanthanide mono- and diphosphonates.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compounds 1-3 are the first members of lanthanide oxalate tetraphosphonates. They form two different types of 3D network structures. Their structures can be viewed as lanthanide phosphonate-based networks being decorated by oxalate anions. Results of this study provide further evidence that we can greatly improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide tetraphosphonates by introducing oxalic acid as the second metal linker. Such a technique has been used successfully in designing luminescent lanthanide mono- and diphosphonates.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the La(II) ion in 1 is eight-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of two chelating oxalate anions, and four phosphonate oxygen atoms from four H6L anions. The La−O distances are in the range of 2.419(3)−2.652(4) Å. Its coordination geometry can be described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. O(11), O(12), O(22), O(23), O(2), and O(3) form a trigonal prism whereas O(1) and O(4) act as capping atoms (See Supporting Information). Each oxalate anion is tetradentate and forms two La−O−C−C−O five-membered chelating rings. The H6L anion is octadentate and bridges with eight La(III) ions. All four phosphonate groups of the H6L anion are singly protonated, as are the amine groups.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure , the La(II) ion in 1 is eight-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of two chelating oxalate anions, and four phosphonate oxygen atoms from four H6L anions. The La-O distances are in the range of 2.419(3)-2.652(4) Å. Its coordination geometry can be described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. O(11), O(12), O(22), O(23), O(2), and O(3) form a trigonal prism whereas O(1) and O(4) act as capping atoms (See Supporting Information). Each oxalate anion is tetradentate and forms two La-O-C-C-O five-membered chelating rings. The H6L anion is octadentate and bridges with eight La(III) ions. All four phosphonate groups of the H6L anion are singly protonated, as are the amine groups.

Symmetry codes: (a) x + 1, y, z; (b) x + 1, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (c) x, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (d) -x + 1, -y, -z + 1; (e) -x + 2, -y, -z + 1; (f) -x, -y, -z; (g) x - 1, y, z; (h) x - 1, -y + 1/2, z - 1/2; (i) x, -y + 1/2, z - 1/2.

elements.content: The interconnection of La(III) by chelating and bridging oxalate anions results in a 1D zigzag chain of {La(C2O4)}+ along the a axis (Figure a). The dihedral angle between two five-membered chelating rings sharing a common La(III) atom is 67.8°. The cross-linkage of La(III) ions by bridging H6L anions led to a 3D network with tunnels along the a-axis (Figure b). A tunnel is formed by 34-membered atomic rings composed of four La(III) ions, six phosphonate groups, and two N−C−C−C−C−N organic groups (Figure b). The size of the tunnel is estimated to be 4.0 × 6.0 Å2 based on structure data. The structure of 1 can be described as the oxalate anions occupying and bisecting the tunnels of lanthanum(III) tetraphosphonate with the lattice water molecules located at the thus-formed small tunnels along the a axis (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The interconnection of La(III) by chelating and bridging oxalate anions results in a 1D zigzag chain of {La(C2O4)}+ along the a axis (Figure a). The dihedral angle between two five-membered chelating rings sharing a common La(III) atom is 67.8°. The cross-linkage of La(III) ions by bridging H6L anions led to a 3D network with tunnels along the a-axis (Figure b). A tunnel is formed by 34-membered atomic rings composed of four La(III) ions, six phosphonate groups, and two N-C-C-C-C-N organic groups (Figure b). The size of the tunnel is estimated to be 4.0 × 6.0 Å2 based on structure data. The structure of 1 can be described as the oxalate anions occupying and bisecting the tunnels of lanthanum(III) tetraphosphonate with the lattice water molecules located at the thus-formed small tunnels along the a axis (Figure ).

elements.content: A 1D zigzag chain of {La(C2O4)}+ (a) and a 3D network of {La2(H6L)}4+ (b) in 1. The phosphonate tetrahedra are shaded in pink. La, N, C, and O atoms are represented by green, blue, black, and red circles, respectively.

elements.content: View of the structure of1 down the a-axis. The phosphonate tetrahedra are shaded in pink. La, N, C, and O atoms are represented by green, blue, black, and red circles, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  View of the structure of1 down the a-axis. The phosphonate tetrahedra are shaded in pink. La, N, C, and O atoms are represented by green, blue, black, and red circles, respectively.

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and their structures feature a different type of 3D network. The structure of the Nd(III) compound will be discussed in detail as an example. As shown in Figure , Nd(1) in 2 is eight-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two oxalate anions, three phosphonate oxygen atoms from three H6L anions, and an aqua ligand. The coordination geometry around the Nd(III) ion can be also described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. O(11), O(21), O(1), O(1w), O(2), and O(3) form a trigonal prism, whereas O(23) and O(4) act as two capping atoms (See Supporting Information). The Nd−O distances range from 2.356(3)−2.541(4) Å, comparable to those reported for other neodymium(III) phosphonates and oxalates. Though the protonation mode of the H6L anion in 2 is the same as that in 1, it adopts a different coordination mode. The H6L anion is hexadentate and bridges with six Nd(III) ions; two of its four phosphonate groups (CP(2)O3 and its symmetrically generated group) are bidentate, whereas the remaining two are unidentate (Figure ). Similar to that in 1, the oxalate groups in 2 form a 1D zigzag {Nd(C2O4)}+ chain along the b-axis. Different from that in 1, the interconnection of Nd(III) ions in 2 via bridging H6L anions led to a (−1 0 1) neodymium phosphonate layer (Figure ). The above two building blocks are interconnected by sharing Nd(III) ions into a pillared-layered architecture with the oxalate groups acting as the pillars, forming narrow, long tunnels along the b axis (Figure ). Alternatively, the structure of 2 can also be viewed as the (2 0 0) neodymium(III)−oxalate−phosphonate hybrid layers being interconnected by the organic diamine groups (the pillars).
elements.clean_text: Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and their structures feature a different type of 3D network. The structure of the Nd(III) compound will be discussed in detail as an example. As shown in Figure , Nd(1) in 2 is eight-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two oxalate anions, three phosphonate  oxygen atoms from three H6L anions, and an aqua ligand. The coordination geometry around the Nd(III) ion can be also described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. O(11), O(21), O(1), O(1w), O(2), and O(3) form a trigonal prism, whereas O(23) and O(4) act as two capping atoms (See Supporting Information). The Nd-O distances range from 2.356(3)-2.541(4) Å, comparable to those reported for other neodymium(III) phosphonates and oxalates. Though the protonation mode of the H6L anion in 2 is the same as that in 1, it adopts a different coordination mode. The H6L anion is hexadentate and bridges with six Nd(III) ions; two of its four phosphonate groups (CP(2)O3 and its symmetrically generated group) are bidentate, whereas the remaining two are unidentate (Figure ). Similar to that in 1, the oxalate groups in 2 form a 1D zigzag {Nd(C2O4)}+ chain along the b-axis. Different from that in 1, the interconnection of Nd(III) ions in 2 via bridging H6L anions led to a (-101) neodymium phosphonate layer (Figure ). The above two building blocks are interconnected by sharing Nd(III) ions into a pillared-layered architecture with the oxalate groups acting as the pillars, forming narrow, long tunnels along the b axis (Figure ). Alternatively, the structure of 2 can also be viewed as the (200) neodymium(III)-oxalate-phosphonate hybrid layers being interconnected by the organic diamine groups (the pillars).

elements.content: The structural differences between compound 1 and compound 2 (or compound 3) are of interest and deserve further discussion. The different coordination mode of the phosphonate ligand adopted in these compounds certainly plays an important role in the formation of these two different structural types. Another reason may be related to the ionic size of different lanthanide ions, the so-called “lanthanide contraction”. With decreasing ionic size, the heavier lanthanide ion is prone to be hydrated, leaving fewer coordination sites for the phosphonate ligand.
elements.clean_text: The structural differences between compound 1 and compound 2 (or compound 3) are of interest and deserve further discussion. The different coordination mode of the phosphonate ligand adopted in these compounds certainly plays an important role in the formation of these two different structural types. Another reason may be related to the ionic size of different lanthanide ions, the so-called "lanthanide contraction". With decreasing ionic size, the heavier lanthanide ion is prone to be hydrated, leaving fewer coordination sites for the phosphonate ligand.

elements.content: Compound 1 is stable up to 140 °C; then it shows three main steps of weight losses (Figure ). The first step, from 140 to 220 °C, corresponds to the release of the two lattice water molecules. The observed weight loss of 5% is slightly larger than the calculated value (3.8%). The second step covers from 220 to 510 °C, during which the organic groups are partially burnt. The third step, from 805 to 1000 °C, corresponds to the further decomposition of the compound. The final residuals are LaPO4 and LaP3O9 based on XRD powder studies. The observed total weight loss of 37.5% is slightly larger than the theoretical one (35.9%). TGA curves for 2 and 3 are similar and exhibit three main steps of weight losses. The Eu compound was used as an example (Figure ). The weight loss between 109 and 173 °C corresponds to the release of the four lattice water molecules. The observed weight loss of 7.0% is slightly larger than the calculated value (6.0%). The second step began at 173 °C and was complete at 510 °C, during which the aqua ligands are removed and the compound is partially decomposed. The third step covers from 820 to 1000 °C, during which the organic groups are burnt. The final residuals are EuPO4 and EuP3O9 based on XRD powder studies. The observed total weight loss of 39.2% matches well with the theoretical one (39.4%).
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 is stable up to 140 °C; then it shows three main steps of weight losses (Figure ). The first step, from 140 to 220 °C, corresponds to the release of the two lattice water molecules. The observed weight loss of 5% is slightly larger than the calculated value (3.8%). The second step covers from 220 to 510 °C, during which the organic groups are partially burnt. The third step, from 805 to 1000 °C, corresponds to the further decomposition of the compound. The final residuals are LaPO4 and LaP3O9 based on XRD powder studies. The observed total weight loss of 37.5% is slightly larger than the theoretical one (35.9%). TGA curves for 2 and 3 are similar and exhibit  three main steps of weight losses. The Eu compound was used as an example (Figure ). The weight loss between 109 and 173 °C corresponds to the release of the four lattice water molecules. The observed weight loss of 7.0% is slightly larger than the calculated value (6.0%). The second step began at 173 °C and was complete at 510 °C, during which the aqua ligands are removed and the compound is partially decomposed. The third step covers from 820 to 1000 °C, during which the organic groups are burnt. The final residuals are EuPO4 and EuP3O9 based on XRD powder studies. The observed total weight loss of 39.2% matches well with the theoretical one (39.4%).

elements.content: Luminescent Properties. The solid-state luminescent properties of 1−3 were investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of 1−3 are shown in Figure . Under excitation of 360 nm, 1 displays a broad blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 435 nm (Figure a), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Compound 2 shows the characteristic emission bands for the Nd(III) ion (Figure b) in the near-IR region:  two moderate emission bands at 875 and 894 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2), a very strong emission band at 1056 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), and a very weak band at 1328 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near-IR region. The splitting of the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 transition band is due to the “crystal field effect” of the Nd(III) ion located at a C 1 site. Compound 3 exhibits four sets of characteristic emission bands for the Eu(III) ion in the visible region under excitation at 267 nm (Figure c). These emission bands are 578.5 nm (very weak, 5D0 → 7F0), 587.5, 590.0, and 592.5 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F1), 610.5, 617.0, and 620.5 nm (very strong, 5D0 → 7F2), and 688, 690.5, 694, 698, and 701 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F4). The splitting of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4 transition bands is due to the “crystal field effect” of the Eu(III) ion in a C 1 symmetry, which led to the complete degeneracy of the 7F1 and the partial degeneracy of the 7F j (j = 2 and 4) states. The Eu (5D0) lifetime (λex,em = 267, 617 nm) of 3 is measured to be 0.38 ms.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent Properties. The solid-state luminescent properties of 1-3 were investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of 1-3 are shown in Figure . Under excitation of 360 nm, 1 displays a broad blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 435 nm (Figure a), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Compound 2 shows the characteristic emission bands for the Nd(III) ion (Figure b) in the near-IR region: two moderate emission bands at 875 and 894 nm (4F3/2 → 4I9/2), a very strong emission band at 1056 nm (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), and a very weak band at 1328 nm (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near-IR region. The splitting of the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 transition band is due to the "crystal field effect" of the Nd(III) ion located at a C 1 site. Compound 3 exhibits four sets of characteristic emission bands for the Eu(III) ion in the visible region under excitation at 267 nm (Figure c). These emission bands are 578.5 nm (very weak, 5D0 → 7F0), 587.5, 590.0, and 592.5 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F1), 610.5, 617.0, and 620.5 nm (very strong, 5D0 → 7F2), and 688, 690.5, 694, 698, and 701 nm (weak, 5D0 → 7F4). The splitting of 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, and 5D0 → 7F4 transition bands is due to the "crystal field effect" of the Eu(III) ion in a C 1 symmetry, which led to the complete degeneracy of the 7F1 and the partial degeneracy of the 7F j  (j = 2 and 4) states. The Eu (5D0) lifetime (λex,em = 267, 617 nm) of 3 is measured to be 0.38 ms.

elements.content: These results indicate that 1 is capable of producing blue light in electroluminescent devices, whereas 2 is a luminescent material in the near-IR region, and 3 is a good candidate for red-light emitting luminescent material.
elements.clean_text: These results indicate that 1 is capable of producing blue light in electroluminescent devices, whereas 2 is a luminescent material in the near-IR region, and 3 is a good candidate for red-light emitting luminescent material.

elements.content: In summary, the hydrothermal syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of three novel rare-earth oxalate tetraphosphonates have been described. Their structures can be viewed as lanthanide-phosphonate-based networks being decorated by oxalate anions. Compounds 1−3 are new rare-earth compounds with blue, red luminescent, and near-infrared emission. Our studies show that we can greatly improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide tetraphosphonates by introducing oxalic acid as the second metal linker. This synthetic technique also allows us to design new types of lanthanide complexes with novel crystal structures and luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the hydrothermal syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of three novel rare-earth oxalate tetraphosphonates have been described. Their structures can be viewed as lanthanide-phosphonate-based networks being decorated by oxalate anions. Compounds 1-3 are new rare-earth compounds with blue, red luminescent, and near-infrared emission. Our studies show that we can greatly improve the solubility and crystallinity of lanthanide tetraphosphonates by introducing oxalic acid as the second metal linker. This synthetic technique also allows us to design new types of lanthanide complexes with novel crystal structures and luminescent properties.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic files for compounds 1, 2, and 3 in CIF format and a figure showing the coordination geometries around the lanthanide ions. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

X-ray crystallographic files for compounds 1, 2, and 3 in CIF format and a figure showing the coordination geometries around the lanthanide ions. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Preparation of [La 2 (ox) 2 (H 6 L)] · 2H 2 O (1) and Ln 2 (ox) 2 (H 6 L)(H 2 O) 2 · 4H 2 O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3). The methods used for the syntheses of the three compounds are similar. A mixture of 0.2 mmol Ln2O3 (0.065 g of La2O3, 0.067 g of Nd2O3, or 0.070 g of Eu2O3), 0.2 mmol H8L (0.092 g), and 0.40 mmol H2C2O4 (0.050 g) in 10 mL of distilled water was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (25 mL) and then heated at 180 °C for 5 days. Crystals of 1 (colorless, brick), 2 (purple, plate), and 3 (colorless, needle) were collected in ca. 77%, 78%, and 73% yield, respectively (based on lanthanide). The initial and final pH values of the resultant solution are about 3.5 and 4.5, respectively. Elemental analysis for 1:  C12H26La2N2O22P4 (M r = 952.05). Calcd:  C, 15.13; H, 2.73; N, 2.94%. Found:  C, 15.29; H, 2.66; N, 2.85%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3405(s), 3005(s), 2768(m), 1695(m), 1470(vs), 1312(s), 1175(vs), 1111(s), 1070(s), 988(s), 928(s), 791(s), 725(m), 604(m), 570(s), 467(s). Elemental analysis for 2:  C12H34N2Nd2O26P4 (M r = 1034.77). Calcd:  C, 13.92; H, 3.28; N, 2.70%. Found:  C, 13.78; H, 3.46; N, 2.98%. IR data (KBr, cm-1):  3429(s), 3003(s), 2778(s), 2613, 1660(vs), 1446(s), 1313(s), 1154(s), 992(s), 936(s), 791(m), 718(s), 606(m), 568(m), 530(m). Elemental analysis for 3:  C12H34N2Eu2O26P4 (M r = 1050.21). Calcd:  C, 13.71; H, 3.24; N, 2.67%. Found:  C, 13.29; H, 3.46; N, 2.75%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3427(vs), 2614(m), 1706(s), 1631(vs), 1457(m), 1318(s), 1091(vs), 1017(s), 937(s), 790(s), 717(m), 607(s), 554(s), 532(s), 492(s).

The methods used for the syntheses of the three compounds are similar. A mixture of 0.2 mmol Ln2O3 (0.065 g of La2O3, 0.067 g of Nd2O3, or 0.070 g of Eu2O3), 0.2 mmol H8L (0.092 g), and 0.40 mmol H2C2O4 (0.050 g) in 10 mL of distilled water was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (25 mL) and then heated at 180 °C for 5 days. Crystals of 1 (colorless, brick), 2 (purple, plate), and 3 (colorless, needle) were collected in ca. 77%, 78%, and 73% yield, respectively (based on lanthanide). The initial and final pH values of the resultant solution are about 3.5 and 4.5, respectively. Elemental analysis for 1: C12H26La2N2O22P4 (M r = 952.05). Calcd: C, 15.13; H, 2.73; N, 2.94%. Found: C, 15.29; H, 2.66; N, 2.85%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3405(s), 3005(s), 2768(m), 1695(m), 1470(vs), 1312(s), 1175(vs), 1111(s), 1070(s), 988(s), 928(s), 791(s), 725(m), 604(m), 570(s), 467(s). Elemental analysis for 2: C12H34N2Nd2O26P4 (M r = 1034.77). Calcd: C, 13.92; H, 3.28; N, 2.70%. Found: C, 13.78; H, 3.46; N, 2.98%. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3429(s), 3003(s), 2778(s), 2613, 1660(vs), 1446(s), 1313(s), 1154(s), 992(s), 936(s), 791(m), 718(s), 606(m), 568(m), 530(m). Elemental analysis for 3: C12H34N2Eu2O26P4 (M r = 1050.21). Calcd: C, 13.71; H, 3.24; N, 2.67%. Found: C, 13.29; H, 3.46; N, 2.75%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3427(vs), 2614(m), 1706(s), 1631(vs), 1457(m), 1318(s), 1091(vs), 1017(s), 937(s), 790(s), 717(m), 607(s), 554(s), 532(s), 492(s).
